questions.question_text:
Your company has an Azure subscription named Sub1.

You plan to create several security alerts by using Azure Monitor.

You need to prepare Sub1 for the alerts.

What should you create first?

discussion.content: C. An Azure Log Analytics workspace

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.
C is the an answer , as Monitor works on Log Analytics workspace

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains the Azure App Service web apps shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You upload a private key certificate named Cert1.pfx to App1.

Which apps can use Cert1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I would go with as as per below explanation

After you add a private certificate to an app, the certificate is stored in a deployment unit that's bound to the App Service plan's resource group, region, and operating system combination, internally called a webspace. That way, the certificate is accessible to other apps in the same resource group, region, and OS combination. Private certificates uploaded or imported to App Service are shared with App Services in the same deployment unit.

Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/configure-ssl-certificate?tabs=apex

comments.content: Sorry missed the answer: it would be A

discussion.content:
After you add a private certificate to an app, the certificate is stored in a deployment unit that's bound to the App Service plan's resource group, region, and operating system combination, internally called a webspace. That way, the certificate is accessible to other apps in the same resource group, region, and OS combination. Private certificates uploaded or imported to App Service are shared with App Services in the same deployment unit.

You can add up to 1000 private certificates per webspace.
I think A

Store certificate in Azure Key Vault: make sure to use the same subscription and resource group as your App Service app. For that reason only App1 and App2 can use Certificate. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/configure-ssl-app-service-certificate?tabs=portal
Why not A?
When you upload a certificate to App Service, it's stored in the App Service instance's Key Vault. Key Vault is a global service in Azure, meaning it can be accessed from different regions.

Selected Answer: A
To support the answer:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/defender-for-cloud/quickstart-onboard-aws

Connect your AWS account
To connect your AWS to Defender for Cloud by using a native connector:
Sign in to the Azure portal.
Go to Defender for Cloud > Environment settings.
Select Add environment > Amazon Web Services.
Answer = A

Selected Answer: A
Configure the Environment settings.

Explanation:

 • Environment Settings in Defender for Cloud: This is where you manage the integration of external cloud environments such as AWS and GCP with Microsoft Defender for Cloud. By configuring the environment settings, you can onboard your AWS account, set up the necessary connectors, and establish monitoring and security management.

choices.B: From the AWS account, enable a security hub.
choices.A: From Defender for Cloud, configure the Environment settings.
choices.C: From Defender for Cloud, configure the Security solutions settings.
choices.D: From the Azure portal, add the AWS enterprise application.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Cloud.

You have an Amazon Web Services (AWS) account.

You need to add the AWS account to Defender for Cloud.

What should you do first?

discussion.content:
Question is pretty old and now when creating Storage Account, you can select what services you want to protect with customer managed keys.
You can select either "blobs and files" or "all service types". Note that you can't change this setting after creation of storage account

Selected Answer: AD
Correct. See:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-service-encryption#about-encryption-key-management

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure key vault.

You create a storage account named storage1.

You plan to store data in the following storage1 services:
• Azure Files
• Azure Blob storage
• Azure Table storage
• Azure Queue storage

For which two services can you configure data encryption by using the keys stored in the key vault? Each correct answer presents a complete solution,

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
From the material I have, there is additional line below as following:
Which 2 actions should you perform? Each answer presents part of the solution.
ANS: B & D
B: Enable Azure Network Watcher
D: Enable NSG flow logs.
There is a E selection, which is not the correct answer anyway.
E: Create an Azure Log Analytics workspace
Just watch out for the real question.
Given answer is correct because the requirement is logging network traffic

Here The steps for it.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/nsg-flow-logs-tutorial

Selected Answer: D
D. Enable NSG flow logs.

Selected Answer: D
D. Enable NSG flow logs.
The answer is correct

Selected Answer: D
D. Enable NSG flow logs.
I take it now that AMA is the preferred agent from DfC, this is an old question and no longer valid.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct answer. 

Key word is log the "network" traffic not diagnostics.
#exam ques # 29 Sep
Got this in the AZ-500 exam (Sept 2021)! A: D
highlight network traffic

C is tempting. Although you can enable diagnostic extension for NSG Resource group, it provides logs for the NGS itself not for the flows that go through the NGS. NGS flow logs on other hand can be used to provide the flow logs and you store these logs in an AZ storage a/c.
Answer is correct : D

comments.content: Network security group (NSG) flow logs is a feature of Azure Network Watcher that allows you to log information about IP traffic flowing through an NSG. Flow data is sent to Azure Storage accounts from where you can access it as well as export it to any visualization tool, SIEM, or IDS of your choice.

discussion.content: Answer: B

questions.question_text:
You have 10 virtual machines on a single subnet that has a single network security group (NSG).
You need to log the network traffic to an Azure Storage account.
What should you do?

choices.B: Create an Azure Log Analytics workspace.
choices.A: Install the Network Performance Monitor solution.
choices.C: Enable diagnostic logging for the NSG.
